extractions.description: The paper investigates the application of two safety engineering frameworks, Failure Mode and Effects Analysis (FMEA) and System Theoretic Process Analysis (STPA), to identify potential social and ethical risks in the development and use of text-to-image (T2I) models. The authors conducted a case study focusing on various stages of the ML product development pipeline, including data processing, model integration, and end-use by artists. The research reveals that examining interactions and processes through these frameworks can uncover a range of failures and hazards beyond performance metrics of a single model.

title.value: Beyond the ML Model: Applying Safety Engineering Frameworks to Text-to-Image Development
title.justification: This is the title of the paper as presented in the provided text.
title.quote: Beyond the ML Model: Applying Safety Engineering Frameworks to Text-to-Image Development

type.justification: The research involves the application of established safety engineering frameworks to real-world processes and models, supplemented by workshops and interviews with practitioners and artists, to gather empirical evidence on the efficacy of these frameworks.
type.quote: We focus on the application of FMEA and STPA at three stages of the ML development and deployment pipeline: (1) data processing for creating a training dataset, (2) integration of one ML model with other ML or non-ML algorithms in an ML-product, and (3) end use of the ML product.

research_field.justification: The research addresses the development and deployment of machine learning models, specifically focusing on deep learning frameworks for text-to-image models.
research_field.quote: We focus on the application of FMEA and STPA at three stages of the ML development and deployment pipeline: data processing for creating a training dataset, integration of one ML model with other ML or non-ML algorithms in an ML-product, and end use of the ML product.

sub_research_field.justification: The paper specifically discusses the identification and management of risks (social, ethical, and functional) in the development and deployment pipeline of T2I models using safety engineering frameworks.
sub_research_field.quote: Results of our analysis demonstrate the safety frameworks – both of which are not designed explicitly examine social and ethical risks – can uncover failure and hazards that pose social and ethical risks.

name.justification: The paper mentions DALL-E in the context of discussing T2I models that have been developed.
name.quote: Such models, including DALL-E [58], Parti [84], Stable Diffusion [19], and Imagen [68] are generative T2I models.

type.justification: DALL-E 2 is a well-known text-to-image generative model, which aligns with the type of model discussed in the paper.
type.quote: Such models, including DALL-E [58], Parti [84], Stable Diffusion [19], and Imagen [68] are generative T2I models.

name.justification: The paper used the publicly available data card for the Parti model, which is based on the FIT400M dataset, as a basis for its analysis of the data processing stage.
name.quote: For our proof-of-concept analysis, we use the data processing steps outlined in the publicly available data card for the Parti model [17].
